I really believe that all the years of HCV that Knievel lived with, and almost died from, finally caught up with him.  I would suspect that the diabetes, strongly associated with HCV (and now even considered caused directly by HCV), and also the pulmonary fibrosis (fibrosis folks, as in liver fibrosis!) were fallout from the HCV.  They always say how many people die WITH HCV, but not from it.......well NOT exactly!  Many don't die from the major, well recognized HCV issues...liver failure or HCC...but  die instead from some other deadly syndrome caused by HCV either directly of indirectly...like cerebral hemorrhage (Anita Roddick), diabetes, heart attack, etc. This relationship has not been studied nearly enough to realize how many problems really stem from the virus, and how these issues also lead to premature death.  But they are beginning to get looked at very closely lately.Many of these major medical problems are just beginning to be understood to be a consequence of long term HCV infection.  Let's not let the virus off too easily!  It has many ways of damaging lives, and also ending them.  The liver threat is just the most obvious, and currently understood problem.Let's hope that the 'cure', or SVR, is protective from all of these fatal consequences....not just tle liver related ones!DoubleDose

Seems to match the 65 year problem age for Hep C sufferers, per another thread.Evel Knievel dies at 69MITCH STACYThe Associated PressNovember 30, 2007 at 4:22 PM ESTClearwater, Fla. — Evel Knievel, the hard-living motorcycle daredevil whose exploits made him an international icon in the 1970s, died Friday. He was 69.Knievel's death was confirmed by his granddaughter, Krysten Knievel. He had been in failing health for years, suffering from diabetes and idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, an incurable condition that scarred his lungs.Knievel had undergone a liver transplant in 1999 after nearly dying of hepatitis C, likely contracted through a blood transfusion after one of his bone-shattering spills.
